ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: In comparison to other racial minorities (e.g., African American, Hispanics, Native Americans): Asians/Asian Americans have stronger work ethics.
Notes: 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Somewhat disagree; 3= Slightly disagree; 4= Neither agree nor disagree; 5= Slightly agree; 6= Somewhat agree; 7= Strongly agree

ElementDescription: In comparison to other racial minorities (e.g., African American, Hispanics, Native Americans): Asians/Asian Americans are harder workers.
Notes: 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Somewhat disagree; 3= Slightly disagree; 4= Neither agree nor disagree; 5= Slightly agree; 6= Somewhat agree; 7= Strongly agree

ElementDescription: In comparison to other racial minorities (e.g., African American, Hispanics, Native Americans): Despite experiences with racism, Asians/Asian Americans are more likely to achieve academic and economic success.
Notes: 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Somewhat disagree; 3= Slightly disagree; 4= Neither agree nor disagree; 5= Slightly agree; 6= Somewhat agree; 7= Strongly agree

ElementDescription: In comparison to other racial minorities (e.g., African American, Hispanics, Native Americans): Asians/Asian Americans are more motivated to be successful.
Notes: 1= Strongly disagree; 2= Somewhat disagree; 3= Slightly disagree; 4= Neither agree nor disagree; 5= Slightly agree; 6= Somewhat agree; 7= Strongly agree

ElementDescription: In comparison to other racial minorities (e.g., African American, Hispanics, Native Americans): Asians/Asian Americans generally have higher grade point averages (i.e., GPA) in school because academic success is more important.

ElementDescription: In comparison to other racial minorities (e.g., African American, Hispanics, Native Americans): Asians/Asian Americans are more likely to persist through tough situations.
